roleset.name: to have an effect on [most common meaning]
roleset.note: AFFECT-V NOTES: Frames file for 'affect' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus; adjectival usage based on BOLT-4,5. Member of Vncls amuse-31.1. (from affect.01-v)
EFFECT-N NOTES: Based on verb entry affect.01; corresponds to Vncls amuse-31.1. Differs from verb frame in arg2 because mention of affect itself is possible with noun. (from effect.01-n)
AFFECTED-J NOTES: Automatically created by Julia as an alias file for unification. (from affected.01-j)

example.name: simple transitive
example.text: The funding mechanism would affect the antitrust operations of the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission.
example.arg: the antitrust operations of the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission

example.name: Adjectival rel (according to treebank): affected
example.text: Even people with good credit and little debt will be affected.
example.arg: people with good credit and little debt

example.name: Within LVC, args 0 & 1
example.text: Another graduate of a Taiwan institution declares bluntly that he only spent four years in Taiwan getting his degree , and the place had virtually no effect on him at all .

example.name: Arg2
example.text: Not an unreasonable admonition, really, but it had the effect of muzzling Galileo on the matter.
example.arg: of muzzling Galileo on the matter.

example.name: copycat
example.text: Salesmen will affect the accent of the region of the country they are calling.
example.arg: the accent of the region of the country they are calling.

roleset.name: to put into effect, to take effect
roleset.note: WARNING: Use affect.01 for "to have an effect."
The difference between 'effect' and 'affect' is one of the great pitfalls of English. 'To affect' means to influence, 'to effect' means to bring about or execute.

example.name: perilous example
example.text: [Mr. Dang]-1 is alleged [*-1]-2 to have used the account of Singapore hotel and property magnate Ong Beng Seng [*-2] to effect the transactions.

example.name: proper lexical item
example.text: But even if he effects a Hyde-to-Jekyll transformation, he will face a serious ideological crisis and Reunification ScenarioTwo.

example.name: effect-n: in LVC
example.text: The revisions will take effect Friday.

roleset.name: cause an effect, successful in creating a desired effect
roleset.note: EFFECTIVE-J NOTES: Added by Julia based on BOLT-1, effect-v.01. (from effective.01-j)

role.descr: domain in which arg0 is effective; outcome effected

example.name: both args with EXT
example.text: They note that it is 87 % effective in preventing people in that range from getting the flu at all but people in the 18 - 49range only had lessened symptoms .
example.arg: in preventing people in that range from getting the flu at all

frameset.note: Usage note from AHD: Affect and effect are often confused because they sound alike and have related meanings. First, bear in mind that there are two words spelled affect. One means "to put on a false show of," as in She affected a British accent. The other affect, the one that is confused with effect, is both a noun and a verb. As a noun it is uncommon and means roughly "emotion." It is pronounced with stress on the first syllable rather than the second. Note that affect does not have a noun sense meaning "an influence that brings about a change." As a verb, affect is most commonly used in the sense of "to cause a change in:" the ways in which smoking affects health. The verb effect means "to bring about or execute": medical treatment designed to effect a cure. Its corresponding noun means "a result." Thus if someone affects something, there is likely to be an effect of some kind, and from this may arise some of the confusion. People who stop smoking will see beneficial health effects, but not beneficial health affects. The verbs produce important differences in meaning. The sentence These measures have been designed to effect savings implies that the measures will cause new savings to come about. Using affect in the very similar sentence These measures will affect savings implies that the measures will cause a change in savings that have already been realized.
